Award.AwardTitle: NSWP: Next Generation AMIE: Assimilative Mapping of Space-based and Extremely Localized Observations of Ionospheric Electrodynamics
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will make significant enhancements to Assimilative Mapping Ionospheric Electrodynamics (AMIE) model, and will use the new capabilities to investigate several scientific questions of fundamental importance to magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling and dynamic space weather events. Specifically, the model will be constructed using a spherical wavelet basis, affording better representation of fine structure, and will specify magnetic potential associated with inclined magnetic field lines. Conductances will be incorporated more accurately, and an assimilative framework will be added to allow for the time evolution of the state variables and the adaptive update of error covariances. Furthermore, space-based data from AMPERE, DMSP, POES, CHAMP, and additional new sources will be assimilated. The updated AMIE model will be used for a series of event studies to investigate localized and global energy deposition and plasma convection at high latitudes, important drivers for the thermosphere/ionosphere system which can have large effects on communication and navigation systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The polar ionosphere plays an important role in the Sun-Earth connection chain, hosting the most dynamic electromagnetic energy and momentum exchange processes between the upper atmosphere and the magnetosphere. Specification of the electrodynamic state of the polar ionosphere is of paramount interest to the space science community. It defines one of the major driving forces of the thermosphere and ionosphere system and provides us with a means to probe physical processes in the distant magnetosphere. The project advanced the capability of a community data assimilation tool, Assimilative Mapping Ionospheric Electrodynamics (AMIE) to better estimate the ionospheric electrodynamics states from a combination of observations from multiple instruments.  To maximize the utility of recent geospace observations, AMIE NextGen accounts for considerably more realistic uncertainty information associated with observations and a prior model. Uncertainty is characterized in terms of principal components estimated from a large data set, including plasma drifts observed by a global international network of high-frequency radars, auroral particle energy spectrum observed by Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) satellites, and magnetic fields observed by the Iridium constellation and DMPS satellites.  Another area of improvement concerns ionospheric conductivity, which serves as a critical linkage in coupling between the magnetosphere and ionosphere. The project significantly improved the conductance estimation based on the electron precipitation spectra sampled by the DMSP F6 F8 F16 F18 spacecraft using the Global Airglow model. Furthermore, the optimization problem is now solved in terms of the magnetic potential for space-based magnetometer data to make the best use of the Iridium magnetometer data.  In addition, a new type of multi-resolution needlet basis function was developed for analysis of electrodynamic vector fields to be able to resolve highly localized features of high-latitude electrodynamics. The project yielded more than 10 peer-reviewed publications.

The proposed project contributed to the training of two graduate students in the Aerospace Engineering Department and two graduate students in the Statistics Department through direct involvement with the project, and many more students through a tutorial on data assimilation at a CEDAR-GEM joint workshop in 2011 and through a CEDAR workshop in 2014.  The project served as a platform for interdisciplinary collaboration between statisticians and space scientists, and some of the recent developments in advanced spatial statistics will be made available to the space science community. AMIE NextGen software is now being converted in Python for public use.
